I think separating this out is good, but the package naming is wrong. (I wasn't following fully when we discussed it in Discord, sorry.) The problem is that it moves us *away* from npm-ready package names, because `@ember/debug/-basic` is *not* a legal package name. Instead, we probably want something like `@ember/-debug-basic` or `@ember/-basic-debug`, which per your comment to me is probably a good foundation for `@ember/debug` itself at some point. In the very near term, that's the part we care about most for being able to actually roll up our types without doing the shenanigans we are in #20316.

(For lookers-on, what Peter and I had discussed is: We can deprecate any other bits, move out the parts which are built on top of both `debug` and `-internals` into their own package, and then remove the `-debug-basic` once it's no longer needed.)

The utility of this is obvious, of course, so *if* we keep the registry I think we should do it. My hesitation is that we need to make two decisions here before stabilization:

- whether to support the string-based registries *at all*
- what, if any, changes to make to them given the opportunity we have to make some long-needed breaking changes (e.g., should they refer to the class instead of the instance type?)

Notably, at this point the *only* place where the registries are useful constructs is in `lookup`. Accordingly, Iâ€™d like to discuss with @dfreeman and @jamescdavis before we merge (and @dfreeman is on vacation this week).

We chatted about this today and we definitely think we should add it, *but* we need to make a tweak to the registry design itself first: we want to go ahead and switch to using the class (not the instance) as the value in the type registryâ€”as we do in Glint. This is a thing we've been thinking about doing for a while, and the migration into Ember for official types seems like a good time to do it.
The other bit is: if we decide it *is* important to change, we can later (a) trivially codemod to it and (b) support migration paths that enable fallbacks. I'm ðŸ‘ðŸ¼ on it with that in view.

Thanks again for working on this! We talked about it today at the Framework Core Team meeting, and noted that there were a couple gaps between the RFC which introduced `unique-id` and the actual implementation:

- the introduction of plain old functions as helpers via [RFC #0756: Default Helper Manager](https://rfcs.emberjs.com/id/0756-helper-default-manager)
- the lack of an import in support of template strict mode and first-class component templates
- the lack of a clear definition of 

These are *not* your responsibility to address as part of this change, however, so weâ€™ve come up with a path that provides the public import we need for `<template>` support, as outlined in the rest of this review.

If youâ€™re interested, we need to do some work separately to solve those issues, by writing a small RFC which defines how we should approach helpers like this going forward, not least so they *can* be usable as normal JS functions without the extra bits you'll see below. Let me know if youâ€™re interested in that: @wycats is available to help get that written!

Again, though, the only things we need to do to land *this* are to address the comments in the review. Thanks for doing this!

I think we can quibble on whether the examples copied from the RFCs are actually useful for explaining what the feature is. In the RFC they are more geared towards exhausting most of the possibilities, in a spec-by-examples kind of way. In documentation that may be a bit much and the point kind of gets lost. In other words, we may want to trim it down so that we only have one or two succinct/common use cases that gets the main point across.

That being said, any docs are certainly better than no docs. So if @SergeAstapov wants to do another pass now I think that's great, but otherwise we can also just merge it and let someone else iterate on this another time.

I noted a bunch of places where our `@module` declarations in the docs seem to have been simply wrong, and AFAICT this is one part of why the actual generated module docs are substantially less useful than might have been hoped. Between your reorganization and adding those in, I think it might make a nice win for the docs while we're still on YUIDoc (though a colleague is working on doing the work to transition us to TSDoc-powered docs, almost certainly via TypeDoc). That saidâ€¦ itâ€™s possible these are *intentionally* only showing the top-level module, which while deeply unhelpful may be important for some other reason at the moment?

cc. @jenweber @locks: do we *want* to have only (for example) `@ember/routing` rather than `@ember/routing/route` for the `@module` declarations?

---

A related thought: we should consider whether we might want to introduce a `public`/`private` directory, so that you end up with this for input/output structure:

```
.
â”œâ”€â”€ dist
â”‚Â Â  â”œâ”€â”€ -private
â”‚Â Â  â”‚Â Â  â”œâ”€â”€ internal-only.d.ts
â”‚Â Â  â”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ internal-only.js
â”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ public
â”‚Â Â      â”œâ”€â”€ index.d.ts
â”‚Â Â      â”œâ”€â”€ index.js
â”‚Â Â      â”œâ”€â”€ other.d.ts
â”‚Â Â      â””â”€â”€ other.js
â””â”€â”€ src
    â”œâ”€â”€ -private
    â”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ internal-only.ts
    â””â”€â”€ public
        â”œâ”€â”€ index.ts
        â””â”€â”€ other.ts
```

Once [this Typedoc issue](https://github.com/TypeStrong/typedoc/issues/1937) is resolved, we can theoretically start leveraging package `exports` maps to make it so consumers *cannot* use the `-private` directories (if we so desire), with a very straightforward per-package config:

```json
{
  "exports": {
    ".": "./dist/public/index.js",
    "./package.json": "./package.json",
    "./*": "./dist/public/*.js"
  }
}
```

A large number of these tests don't seem to be using a custom `renderTemplate`, and they shouldn't be issuing a deprecation (if they do, that would mean that applications _basically_ have no way to avoid the deprecation).

Basically, we need make it so that we avoid deprecation if you don't implement your own `renderTemplate`.
Thank you @patocallaghan!

Since we only need to forward the events when someone calls `routerService.on('routeWillChange')`, why don't we implement `on` and setup the wiring there?

Let's go the route of https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/19454, and look up the router service during init. That way we can avoid relying on `{ instantiate: false }`. It does add some small amount of overhead (automatic creation of `service:router`), but in practice I don't think that will matter much and the resulting simplicity of the implementation will be easier to maintain.

Looking good! I left some minor inline comments for tweaks, but we also need to flag this for svelting.

The rough steps for svelting are:

* Add a new export from `packages/@ember/deprecated-features/index.js`, the string value should be `3.11.0-beta.1` (which will be the first tagged release including the deprecation)
* Import that boolean flag and surround any code supporting `isVisible` with a conditional (e.g. `if (EMBER_COMPONENT_IS_VISIBLE) { /* code here */ }`)

Some example PRs adding svelting as part of a deprecation:

* https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/17910
* https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/17540
* https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/16685

The goal here is that any code that is supporting a deprecated feature will (eventually) be able to be stripped from apps that declare that they are "deprecation free" for a given version.

As it stands, this leaks `ApplicationInstance` instances in things like fastboot and non `packages/ember-testing` related tests. In those circumstances many `ApplicationInstance` instances are created and "thrown away" to be garbage collected.

I think an alternative way to solve the same general problem would be to have the `ApplicationInstance` push itself into the `Application`'s `_applicationInstances ` array, then splice itself out of that array in the `ApplicationInstance#willDestroy`.  This setup would avoid leaking the `ApplicationInstance` when things are handled properly (e.g. in non-error conditions) and still provide the cleanup that is needed when things go haywire in a given test...

The test cleanup here is looking really nice! Please keep it up!

Still have the same concerns as mentioned previously about leakage. As of https://github.com/emberjs/ember-test-helpers/pull/237 (which is included in `ember-cli@2.17.0` out of the box) we create a single application instance and call `application.buildInstance()` once for each test in the application (and subsequently destroy them during normal test teardown). The array created to track all created `Ember.ApplicationInstance` instances **will** leak the entire contents of the container for each test (the same leak will occur in fastboot per request).

The simple fix (as mentioned above) is to have the `ApplicationInstance` instances splice their own entry out of the array (possibly by adding a `Ember.Application.prototype.destroyInstance` which would be the inverse of `Ember.Application.prototype.buildInstance`).

I think we need test cases for the following scenarios:

* `router.urlFor('something', { selectedItems: ['a', 'b', 'c'] })` (a query param that is an array)
* `router.urlFor('something', { stuff: null })`
* `router.urlFor('something', { stuff: undefined })`
* `router.urlFor('something', { stuff: 'foo' })` where `something` route defines a custom `serializeQueryParam` method
* Tests defining a controller for the target, where the controller throws an error in `init`. The idea here is to ensure that we are not forcing controller instances to be created when generating the URL (which is a significant part of the performance issues surrounding `{{link-to}}`).

  * with dynamic segments (models) and query params
